element.name: Man O' War by Windsockers, Unknown Cache (1/1)

long-description.p: One part of a wooden shipwreck least likely to be smashed was the figurehead. There are many accounts of wrecks in Skerries which mention that a figurehead was washed ashore. Many were placed in gardens as ornaments and rotted away. . ."

"One of the most remarkable was the Man O War which used to reside on a plinth outside the pub in the district of that name. There was great mystery and confusion about the origin and representation of the figure. Some sources even alleged that the figure was stone."
The pub itself is said to have been constructed around an old drinking tree, if that is so then maybe it’s the same tree that can be seen in the lounge of the pub to this day.

Research has elucidated much of the history, but the classical scholarship of Cormac Lowth identified the figurehead as a representation of Hercules clad in the skin of the Nemean lion which he slew as his first labor. There was a ship named Hercules lost on the Irish coast on 22/3/1799 but the exact location is unclear . . .

"The subjects of figureheads were varied. Deep sea vessels tended to have human figures. . . The more profitable the trade the more likely the ship was to have a figurehead. . . Warships tended to have huge elaborate figureheads to symbolize power and majesty. . . but by 1760 the carvings on the warships were more modest and in 1796 the Royal Navy ceased fitting figureheads to new ships."
To find this cache you need to visit various locations to obtain information to lead you to the final location

Part One:
At the above location note the numbers and call them A.B.C.D

Part Two:
Go to N53 33.(A+B)A(A+D) W6 10.(C-A-A)A(A+B)
There you will see some enlightened numbers call them E.F.G.H.I.J.K.L.M.N

p.font: Please take care when parking at the final location there is a hidden ditch nearby that may cause severe damage to vehicles

element.additional-waypoints:
FLWPFV - Final Location
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___
P2WPFV - Part 2
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___

ul.li:
2010-05-13T19:00:00Z : Found it by B&B04
Manowar, Manowar livin' on the Road ... the cache also! Many thanks to show us this small village called like the Kings of Metal. [8D] Many thanks also for the many caches from the Windsockers on the east coast. The cache was a quick found.

2010-03-21T17:11:24Z : Found it by orangetigerprawn
I got stung by the nettles too even though they were very small. I should have searched more with my eyes and avoided getting stung at all.
Tftc.

2009-12-21T20:00:00Z : Found it by sierra-mike
We found it on a walk around Skerries, but the log inside the box was complete frozen and we couldn't log. I'll send a picture to the owner. TFTC!

2009-06-03T19:00:00Z : Found it by auchans
Auchans found it well Joe did, after getting stng by nettles, ripped to shreds by brambles and Electrocuted-----LOL

2009-06-02T19:00:00Z : Owner Maintenance by Windsockers
[green]New log added[/green]

wpt.name: GCWPFV
wpt.desc: Man O' War by Windsockers, Unknown Cache (1/1)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Man O' War
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
One part of a wooden shipwreck least likely to be smashed was the figurehead. There are many accounts of wrecks in Skerries which mention that a figurehead was washed ashore. Many were placed in gardens as ornaments and rotted away. . ."

"One of the most remarkable was the Man O War which used to reside on a plinth outside the pub in the district of that name. There was great mystery and confusion about the origin and representation of the figure. Some sources even alleged that the figure was stone."

The pub itself is said to have been constructed around an old drinking tree, if that is so then maybe it’s the same tree that can be seen in the lounge of the pub to this day.

Research has elucidated much of the history, but the classical scholarship of Cormac Lowth identified the figurehead as a representation of Hercules clad in the skin of the Nemean lion which he slew as his first labor. There was a ship named Hercules lost on the Irish coast on 22/3/1799 but the exact location is unclear . . .

"The subjects of figureheads were varied. Deep sea vessels tended to have human figures. . . The more profitable the trade the more likely the ship was to have a figurehead. . . Warships tended to have huge elaborate figureheads to symbolize power and majesty. . . but by 1760 the carvings on the warships were more modest and in 1796 the Royal Navy ceased fitting figureheads to new ships."

The Cache

To find this cache you need to visit various locations to obtain information to lead you to the final location


Part One:
At the above location note the numbers and call them A.B.C.D


Part Two:
Go to N53 33.(A+B)A(A+D) W6 10.(C-A-A)A(A+B)
There you will see some enlightened numbers call them E.F.G.H.I.J.K.L.M.N


Final location

N53 I(F-G).GIL W 006 (K-E)(J-M).N(G+E)H


Please take care when parking at the final location there is a hidden ditch nearby that may cause severe damage to vehicles



The Windsockers
